summary: Izuku comes home a week after the sludge villain incident to find the apartment nearly empty, his mom gone, her stuff gone, and enough money to pay for a single month's rent. So, being the intelligent motherfucker he is, decides he's going to get his own place, open his own business, and fucking thrive. Oh, and Hawks is his mom now. So there's that.
text:
Izuku sighs to himself as he tapes the large box of limited edition merch closed, and smacks the shipping label on it, he’d kept some from his collection; Hawks, Eraserhead, Present Mic, Midnight, Miruko, Ingenium. He sold all his All Might merch, he just couldn’t look at it the same way anymore, not after the roof top incident, realistic he said, it’s okay to dream, but you have to think about what’s real.

Sighing to himself once more, he hefts the heavy box up, and carries it through the living room to the door, the post man was coming around in a little over an hour to pick it up.

He looks around the sparsely furnished room, his mom had taken all her stuff and left, leaving him with enough money for the month’s rent, and a note telling him how she just couldn’t do it anymore.

Shaking his head, he makes his way back to his room to continue packing his things in boxes, doing so in the silence of the apartment, his mom had stopped paying the phone bill, thus, he had no data, and there hadn’t been any wifi since she disappeared that one day all those weeks ago.

The knocking on the door pulls him out of his self-depreciating thoughts, exiting his room, he makes his way to the door, and pulls it open carelessly. “Hello.”

“Hey kid,” the post man, a short man, balding on top, spares him a small smile. “Package pick up?”

“Um, yea,” the teen lifts the large box. “Here you go, careful, it’s heavy.”

…

Izuku, not Midoriya, he didn’t want to be associated with that name, Izuku has a little over two thousand bucks to his name. He spends it wisely, he knows he needs a source of income, a steady source of income, so he thinks things through, possible job opportunities. People are always hiring for analysists, but then, he’s only fourteen, so that’s extremely unlikely. He could get a job at a café or a store, but then, he’d need a parental signature approving the minor’s permit to work.

Café.

He could open a café.

Make up some story to get the space and thrive from there.

Nodding, he searches through his laptop, on his hotspot, from the mobile plan he’d purchased for himself, searching for vacant properties. He comes across one, small, not overly so, but small enough that it was cozy, asking price was for six hundred and fifty bucks, he could make that work, if he was frugal about it.

He calls the seller.

…

Day one.

His new café is a dump.

There’s no other way to put it.

It’s a dump.

There’s trash everywhere, the lights don’t work, the kitchens trashed, there’s no lock on the door, the counter is rotting through, and that’s just the ground level, the loft upstairs is even worse, no water, cracked pipes, no lights, wall paper peeling, window broken.

It’s a dump.

But, he’s not one to turn away from a challenge, his entire life is one big challenge, admittedly, those with his condition don’t usually make it to his age, so that in itself is quite an accomplishment, one that is both disheartening and something to be proud of.

Izuku leaves for the hardware store, where he checks the discount aisle, finds himself a sledge hammer, gloves, a protective suit, and safety goggles. He stops at the convenience store on his way back to get some hefty strong trash bags, extra-large, and sets to work up his return. Dawning his gear, he takes the first step in renovating his new café, by bashing a large hole into the rotting counter with his new sledge hammer named Bruiser.

He tears out the counter and examines the booths to check for their ability to be salvaged, those, surprisingly, are in good condition, well made products usually are. The first thing he installs that night is a lock on the front door.

The teen gets himself a broom, and starts cleaning out the trash, sweeping up the mess on the floor, peeling the wall paper off the walls, throwing away the old rotten cushions from the booths.

At the end of his first day, he surveys the front room, clean, somewhat, not sanitized yet, and cleared of clutter, all the trash and other non-needed items in a pile where the counter used to be.

He sleeps on the floor of his new café.

…

Day Two.

He wakes up bright and early the next morning, stretches, checks his phone and social media accounts, and sets off to work, starting with lugging the trash and junk out back to the dumpster.

Izuku decides his mission for the day is to get the kitchen taken care of, so, the teen dawns his gear, and begins his work. Tearing off the tiles on the wall, cleaning up the trash littered around the room, tearing the rotten wood off the kitchen pass through between the back room and front room. He tears the pipes out and pulls the appliances out to check on the wiring behind them, like the booths themselves, the wiring connecting the appliances to the wall are intact and good.

He lugs all the trash out to the main room before making another trip to the hardware store, where he purchases new tiles and new plumbing.

Finding videos on YouTube, he manages to learn how to fix the plumbing himself and fix the sink.

At the end of day two, his kitchen is in semi working order, and finds himself with running water.

…

Day Three.

He decides to dedicate the third day to the loft upstairs, which is a monster all on it’s own, but he’s up to the challenge, bring it the fuck on.

The teen’s first wise decision was to push the dumpster up under the upstairs window, making it so much easier to dispose of the garbage bags as they fill up with the garbage littering the loft. He breaks the entire window out with Bruiser, just smashes it, and watches it crash into the dumpster below. The floorboards are rotting, so he pulls them up, one by one, and throws those out the window too. The bathroom is fucking gross, but he soldiers on, tearing it apart, throwing it out the window, and sweeps the upstairs with his broom when everything’s cleared away.

With that done, he works to bring it together, returning to the hardware store, he buys lumber, sealant and stain, a tape measure, a handsaw, nails, and a hammer.

In the front room of the downstairs, he saws the floor boards down to size, stains them, and carries them upstairs, one by one, to reconstruct the floor. By the time he’s got the floor down, his arms are sore, so he takes a break, eating a small sandwich he’d brought from the old apartment, and chugs a bottle of water, before setting off to work again.

Another trip to the hardware store for a glass panel, measure out, he remakes the window, and screws a hook lock on for safety.

He retiles the bathroom, regroups the rub, replaces the shower head, and redoes the plumbing.

Izuku finds himself able to take a shower at his new place on day three.

…

Day Four.

The electric.

That’s a hard one.

A few fixtures have to be rewired, he goes to YouTube for that, gets what he needs from the hardware store, and only electrocutes himself seventeen times.

Surprise, bitches, he’s not dead.

He sets about furnishing the upstairs first, he gets himself a new bedframe, cheap, on sale at Ikea. A new mattress, a big one, so he can stretch out, he gets himself a new dresser, small, he doesn’t have that many clothes to put inside of it, he hangs most of his clothes anyway. A desk, and a desk chair, a kitchen table and some chairs, he gets a fluffy rug because why not, and the necessary things for one to have in their bathroom.

Izuku moves his things to his new home that afternoon in a series of trips and long walks that make his legs burn, but he’s under the impression that the burning means its working, and his body will thank him for the work out later. He sets his merch up to rest on the shelves he installed, sets his lamp on the nightstand, unpacks his boxes of belongings, and takes a minute to survey his new place.

He calls it an early night, considering the day as a job well done, and he’s out by the time his head hits his new pillow.

…

Day Five.

On the fifth day, he does up the kitchen and the front room, he makes another trip to the hardware store for more wood, and rebuilds the counter, he electrocutes himself a total of four times as he rewires the display cases.

He buys new cushions for the booths, paints the walls a soft neutral color, rewires the light fixtures with a total of eight shocks, and cleans the front windows.

The teen retiles the kitchen and scrubs down the appliances.

Izuku makes it nice and cozy, soft colors, rugs, couches along the back walls with pillows. Lamps and mini tables for the floor, if one didn’t want to sit in a booth, and he gets the things one needs for a kitchen, especially a café kitchen.

Day five is the day he finishes his work, challenge completed, I’m a bad bitch you can’t kill me style, and he stands in the middle of his small café with a triumphant smile.

Fuck you, Kacchan, I did accomplish something.

…

“Oh, a cat café!” Izuku tells himself as he eats a muffin, sitting on the edge of the counter, looking around at his masterpiece. “I could do a cat café!” He finishes his muffin and tosses the wrapper in the trashcan behind the counter. “That’d be cool.”

He counts the money he has left, not a whole lot, but he owns the small building, so he doesn’t have to worry about a rent payment or anything.

Making a trip to Target, a few trips to Target, he gets what one would need to get in order to own a cat café, then he goes to a number of shelters, he wants to give them all a forever home, but he knows he can’t, so he takes the ones that are often passed up.

…

His little hole in the wall cat café unironically named ‘Read The Catmosphere!’ gathers a small crowd of people from all walks of life, mainly couples, teens, and the various sketchy looking guys who look like they may be a villain, but he has enough self-preservation not to say anything about it. He makes enough money to enroll himself into online high school courses.

Surprisingly, his little café becomes a popular hangout among the hero community, there he was, minding his own business, refilling the display case when Eraserhead and Present Mic come walking through his front door, he almost passed out, no joke, he literally almost did, but he refrained, took their orders, and internally fanboyed when he was given the impression that they liked his food.

One of them must have shared their experience, because next thing he knows, all these people are showing up. Not that he’s complaining, more people means more customers, and more customers means more money, and more money means more security.

…

“Another day, another dollar.” Izuku mutters to himself as he carries the trash out back to the dumpster behind his hole in the wall Café, lugging it behind him, it was heavy, he had to change out the kitty litter, and that shit was heavy as fuck. “I’m gonna have to replace the light socket in the front room.” He loved the heroes who came to visit him in his café, but sometimes they could get a bit too zealous, and thus, he now had a broken light socket that needed replaced. “Could be worse.”

Grunting under the weight of the trash bag, he swings it up into the dumpster, and jumps, shrieking in surprise, when he hears a soft groan. “What the fuck….?” Creeping around the length of the dumpster, he curls his fingers around the edge, and peers around, eyes widening at who lays there, unconscious to the world around him. “….Hawks?......” He garners no response from the man, not that he expects to, said man is completely dead to the world. “I repeat my previous sentiment, what the fuck?”

Looking down one end of the alley, then down the other, he steps around the edge of the dumpster, and squats in front of the unconscious winged hero, reaching out tentatively to poke him in the cheek. “You okay?” Izuku garners no response, once again, he wasn’t expecting one. “Come on man, not the part of town to be sleeping outdoors.” The man’s taller then him, bigger, he’s a fucking midget, so he ends up dragging him across the alley and in through the back door of his café. He feels a tad bit bad about it, watching his wings drag limply over the dirty asphalt under him, his costume is probably getting all sorts of dirty too. “I’m so sorry man, you can have whatever off the menu for free for the next month, I’ll pay for your dry cleaning too.”

Tugging him inside, he carefully sets the hero down to close and lock the back door, setting the alarm, Café’s closed for the night, cats are fed, litter boxes are nice and fresh, he’s set to retreat upstairs for the night. “Come on man.” Curling his arms under the hero’s arms, around his chest, he lugs the man up the stairs to the apartment above. “How are you so thin but still so heavy, dude!” He’s panting by the time he gets the hero upstairs and takes a minute to catch his breath at the top of the stairs, before turning into his studio apartment. “You can have the bed, I guess, I’ll take the couch.” Izuku drags the man across the threshold, and grunts as he hefts him up, turning his head to avoid a wing to the face, and throws the unconscious hero up onto his bed as best as he can. Panting, he rubs his hands together, and moves around to the foot of the bed to remove the hero’s shoes. “Okay, uh, sleep tight, don’t die, please for the love of god don’t die.”

Izuku eyes the unconscious hero for a minute longer before turning away, nodding to himself, he digs through his dresser for some clothes, spare clothes he’d saved from his dad’s things, and sets them on the nightstand next to the man, writes him a little note, where the bathroom is, etcetera.

Rubbing at the back of his head, he smiles when Biscuit jumps up onto the bed with Nugget, and climbs up to sleep on the hero’s chest, before turning to make his way to the bathroom to take a shower.

…

Keigo is well aware of the warm rumbling weight on his chest when consciousness returns to him, and he groans, reaching up slowly to rub at his face with his hands, blinking his eyes open, he tilts his head when he finds himself staring up at the ceiling of a building, the inside of the ceiling of a building, and looks down to see what the weight on his chest is, eyebrows furrowing when he’s met by the golden eyes of a honey colored cat bathing a kitten on his chest. “Hey….” He lifts the tag on the cat’s collar. “Biscuit and,” he lifts the tag on the kitten’s collar. “Nugget.” Petting their heads, he smiles when they purr louder. “Mind if I get up?”

Neither cat put up a fight when he slowly starts moving, migrating from his chest to the bed, to resume their grooming, and he pushes himself up slowly, eyes catching the stack of folded clothes and note on the nightstand, and reaches out for the slip of paper to skim over the words. “Hmmm.” He hums, setting the note aside, he leans over for the stack of clothes, he doesn’t recognize the room, but he does recognize the cats, he knows he’s in the café, the little owner is around here somewhere. “Shower it is.”

…

Izuku tilts his head when he hears the water turn on, and breathes a sigh of relief, that means the hero’s awake, i.e. not dead. Pulling his ladder up under the light fixture, he carefully climbs up with one hand, setting his tool bag on the top of the ladder, he carefully starts unscrewing the light fixture from the ceiling, and tosses it on the cushion of the booth next to him, and carefully begins taking apart the socket.

It takes him a few minutes, working slow, wanting to get it done right the first time, though he’s got it down, he still doesn’t want to rush it and half ass the job and make a fire hazard waiting to happen.

Fixing the wires in place, he yelps when he shocks himself and his muscles spasm, he falls backwards off his ladder and prepares to meet the floor. Again.

“Woah!” Arms catch him before he makes impact with the floor. “What the hell are you doing?”

Opening his eyes, he meets amused concerned gold, and he smiles. “Oh, hey, you’re awake!”

“Yea, hey,” Hawks carefully sets him on his feet and nods up at the half complete socket. “You just electrocuted yourself, why not get an electrician?”

The teen wipes his hands on his the front of his shirt. “Why pay someone to do something you can do yourself?”

“Um, so you don’t do that.” The hero nods meaningfully at the socket, and the ladder, from which he’d just fallen after electrocuting himself. “You know, you don’t electrocute yourself to death.”

“Oh, please,” he waves a hand at his concerns dismissively. “That’s nothing compared to the one when I first rewired the front room.”

“Excuse me?”

“Don’t worry about it.” Izuku climbs back up his ladder. “I’m pretty sure I’m immortal, lady fate’s been trying to kill me since I was four and hasn’t succeeded yet.” He looks down when he feels the stare, and meets the hero’s gold eyes questioningly, tilting his head in confusion. “What?”

Hawks shakes his head. “I’m not even going to begin unravelling that statement.” He holds his gloves up in offering. “At least use these, they’re shock proof.”

“Oh, cool, thanks.” The teen takes said offering happily, slipping the large gloves on his small hands, and gestures to the kitchen. “Help yourself.”

“Yea,” the hero shakes his head again and turns. “Thanks.”

“Don’t mention it.” Izuku turns his attention back to the socket, listening to the sound of a coffee machine coming to life behind him in the kitchen, and finished rewiring the socket, before replacing the light fixture. “Done and done.” Coming down from his ladder, he throws his tool bag on the closest table, and cracks his back. “Heh, only electrocuted myself once this time.”

“What does that even mean?” He turns to see the hero leaning over the counter with a cup of coffee in one hand. “Only once?”

The greenette tosses the hero’s gloves down on the counter, confiscates his coffee for a moment to take a large gulp, and passes the mug back. “Um, that I only electrocuted myself once this time, what else would it mean?”

Hawks stares at him for a long time, but ultimately appears to decide against commenting further, and quickly changes the subject. “Thanks for bringing me in last night.”

“Hey,” he waves at him. “I’d only want someone to return the favor if they found me passed out in an alley.”

“Why would you be passed out in an alley?”

He throws the man a finger gun. “Reasons.”

“I’m not going to touch that.”

Izuku nods. “Probably for the best.”

…

Izuku’s taking out the trash when he hears it, the soft mew of a small kitty cat in dire need of some help, and who’s he to turn away a small kitty cat in dire need of some help, he took in a hero he found in the back alley who was in dire need of some help who has yet to leave, so it would be a tad bit hypocritical to turn away a small kitty cat in dire need of some help.

Setting the large trash bag down, he searches the space. “Hello, kitty cat?” Another soft mew, two soft mews, two little kitty cats. “Where you at, little kitty cats?”

Shuffling around the trashcans, he searches, water dripping down from his coat hood, the rain pouring over him in torrents.

Moving the last one, he peers in behind the dumpster, and smiles. “There you are.” The two little kittens mew at him and he cautiously reaches in for them. “It’s okay, I’m not gonna hurt you, wanna come in outta the rain?” He holds his hand out, feeling two little wet noses brush against his fingertips. “Can I pick you up?” Carefully, he curls his fingers around the one and lifts it out, tucking it up in his coat, he reaches back out for the other one. “Come on, little fluffballs, let’s go inside.”

Forgoing the bag of trash in front of the dumpster, he makes his way back for the door, reaching out carefully for the door handle, he let’s himself in. Kicking the door closed, he sets the alarm, kicks off his sneakers.

Keigo’s waiting upstairs when he makes his appearance, takes one look at him, and plants his hands on his hips. “How many?”

Izuku smiles sheepishly. “Umm….”

“Nestling,” the hero gives him that look. “How many?”

“Well….” He carefully pulls the kittens out from inside his coat. “Two.”

“Kiddo,” the man eyes the poor wet kitty cats. “You just brought a new one in two days ago.”

“Aw, but Kei, look at’em!” The teen holds the two pitiful kittens up for the hero to see. “They’re so sad!”

The hero heaves a sigh. “Okay, okay, stop making that little puppy pouty face.” He rolls his eyes fondly. “I’ll go get a towel, you, get out of those clothes and into something warm.”

“Okay, dad.” The teen snarks, laughing lightly when the hero tugs on his ear playfully as he passes him, a playful warning, all in good fun. “Come on, little kitties.” Walking over to the cat bed on top of the dresser, he sets his two new family members down, and pets their heads with a finger. “We’ll get you all dry and warm.”

He’s just pulling his sweatshirt on when Keigo returns, he’d given him a few minutes to change in privacy, ‘watching’ with his feathers to know when he was finished. “Okay, you,” he points at himself when the man points at him and the hero nods. “Get under those blankets before you catch a cold. I’ll dry off and tuck in the little kitties.”

Giggling under his breath, he nods, padding over to his big bed, and climbs in on the left, Keigo’s side was the right. He watches the big bad number three hero gently rub the two fluffy kittens dry, tuck a small blanket around them, and set a small bowl of food and water next to them, before tossing the towel over the heater to dry, and making his way into his side of the bed.

“Get in here, hatchling.” Izuku scoots in close when the hero holds his arms open to him, cuddling into his chest, sighing contentedly when arms curl around him. “Getcha all warmed up, you should know better then to stay out in the rain this time of year.”

“Okay mom, I was wearing my coat.”

“Hey!” The kid laughs at the indignation in the hero’s voice. “I am not ‘mom’!”

Izuku nods into the hero’s chest. “Yea, I know. I’ll be fine, papa bird, don’t worry about it.”

“Yea, you say that now, just you wait until you’re walking around here sniffling everywhere you go.” He pulls the blankets up over the youth just a bit more. “You’re gonna be coughing and hacking up lungs, sick as a dog.”

“Calm down, mama bird.” The teen smiles when a wing folds over them. “So, Kei, not that I’m complaining, but it’s been like a month and a half since I dragged your unconscious as—butt in from the alley and you haven’t left yet, do you just live here now or something?”

“Yes.”

Izuku smiles, a real smile, not that his other smiles aren’t real, but this smile is different then the other smiles, and nods in closer. “Cool.”

…

“We should buy the place next door.” That, is not something Izuku is expecting to hear at nine thirty in the morning, and he swears loudly when he drops the pot of freshly brewed coffee. “Woah, hey, fledgling, be careful!” He’s eternally grateful for Keigo when feathers catch the pot before it can hit the floor and shatter.

He looks up at him incredulously. “What!”

Keigo smirks at him, because though he was concerned about possibly burns, he still found it amusing, like the asshole he is. “I said, we should buy the place next door, your little café is starting to become a tad on the popular side, maybe we should expand.”

Shaking himself out, he steps forward, picking up the coffee pot, he steps around the man to return to the front room, pouring Eraserhead (Aizawa—as he’s been told to call him) his fresh large cup of coffee, receiving a grunt of appreciation from the man as he turns to collapse on one of the couches in the back to be cat piled on while enjoying his god juice. “Kei, that’s a lot of work, it took me a week to get this side this way, and I’m still working on it.”

“Yea,” the hero curls around him from behind. “But this time you wouldn’t be doing it on your own, think about it, tear down the separating wall, expand the floor, we could get more cats.”

He turns his head to look up at his new roommate with narrowed eyes. “Are you bribing me with cats?”

“It depends.” Keigo smiles down at him. “Is it working?”

“No.”

It worked.

…

Izuku knew his good week was going to well, he knew something was going to come, it was going to come to a head, he knew it. People like him can’t have nice things, quirkless Deku’s don’t get to have nice things, as soon as they find something they like, someone finds a way to take it from them, it’s just how things worked.

He drops his bags, groceries, cat supplies, refills for the sweeteners and creamers, when he comes to find his café in shambles. Burnt out on the inside, the glass windows broken, the booths and couches charred and singed, the counter still smoldering, and he drops his things, darting inside, his mind still reeling that his livelihood is gone, calling for his kitties, his babies, his best friends (outside of Keigo). Darting up the back steps, two at a time, he’s relieved to find the upstairs apartment virtually untouched, his little feline friends all hiding scattered through the room.

Upon completing a head count and finding everyone present, he returns to the downstairs to take stock of the damage, searching through news feeds for what happened, why his café was in this state.

Endeavor.

He should have known.

Izuku feels tears burn in his eyes as he slowly looks around his burnt cusp of a café, all his hard work, blood, sweat, and tears, all down the drain.

He falls to his knees, tears finally streaming down his face, staring at the remnants of his café.

Time passes by, he doesn’t even realize it, he just sits there in devastation, staring at the tatters and remnants of his world shattered around him. “Fledgling!” He hears something hit the ground outside, boots stomping the pavement, the sound of glass cracking underneath. “Fledgling, are you oka—” The words cut off immediately, interrupted by a deep inhale, glass crackles underneath him as the hero enters their café. “Fledgling, it’ll be okay.” Hands curl around his arms from behind and he just sits there, staring at his ruined café, silent tears streaming down his face. “It’ll be okay, little fledgling, it will.”

Slowly, the teen turns his head, broken green meeting sorrowful gold, and he voice cracks when he finds it. “K—Kei…M—My café…..”

“I know, lil bird.” Keigo nods lightly. “I know, are the cats okay?”

He nods numbly, looking back to his ruined home. “T—They’re upstairs.”

“Good, that’s good, at least our kitties are okay.” Fingers curl under his arms and he’s lifted to his feet. “Come on, hatchling, let’s go pack a bag, we’ll go stay at a hotel until we can get things sorted out.”

“M—My café…..” Izuku can’t tear his eyes away. “P—Papa bird….My c—café….”

“I know, baby bird, I know.” He guides the teen around gently. “Come on, it’s gonna be okay, I promise, we’ll get it all fixed up again, just like before.” The teen nods numbly, letting himself be guided up the stairs, he watches numbly as Keigo packs a bag for him, as an arm is curled around his waist and he’s guided back around, back down the back stares, and out the front door, what was supposed to be the front door. He says nothing, simply exists, when he’s scooped up off his feet.

He doesn’t pay attention enough to see where it is exactly that they fly, he’s in a daze, his mind trying to wrap itself around the fact that his small café is in ruins, his home, everything he’d worked for is gone. He doesn’t hear the conversation that transpires as his hero converses with the woman at the desk, as they’re handed a key, and off they go to their room.

Izuku curls up when he’s set down on their hotel room bed, feeling the man carefully pull his sneakers off and tuck the blankets up around him, the edge of the bed dips as he sits down next to him, combing his fingers through his curls gently. “It’ll be okay, nestling, I promise.”

He finally speaks his first words as he turns to look up at his closest companion. “Promise, Kei?”

The hero nods, rubbing his cheek lightly with his knuckle. “I swear.”

“I don’t know what I’d do without you, Kei.” He rubs a hand over his face. “I’d probably have killed myself.”

“Hey now, don’t talk like that.” Keigo pets his bangs back. “You do have me, that options not even on the table, we’ll get our café fixed up in no time.”

He rubs at his nose. “At least the cats are okay.”

“See, there is some positivity in this.” The man pinches his nose playfully. “Our kitties are just fine, a little startled, but otherwise untouched.”

The teen tugs on the front of the hero’s shirt until he’s forced around, and just flops down on top of him, and the greenette curls his arms around the man’s shoulders, the weight of him resting his head on his chest playing the role of an anchor to keep him from losing his shit at what’s been done to his pride and joy of an establishment.

…

“Okay, you have to the count of three to stop being a Pouty Polly before I stop it myself.” Izuku was not happy that the hero was using his money to fix up his café, he’d lived under the impression, for the last year, of ‘why pay someone to do something you can do yourself’ and he was not happy that this was happening and had every intention to make sure his partner in crime knew this, hence the silent treatment he’d been giving him since breakfast when he’d first told him. “Fledgling, I’m not kidding, stop giving me the silent treatment.”

It didn’t matter to him that as the number three hero, Keigo had more than enough to fund the rehabilitation of their café, he didn’t want to owe him, and it didn’t matter to him that the man swore that he wouldn’t, because under the ‘I owe you’ laws of the universe, he would owe him one no matter how much he denied he did.

“One.”

He turns to glower at the older taller male.

“Two.”

His glare speaks volumes.

“Three.”

He shrieks when he’s swept up off his feet.

“Okay mister, I can see we need to have a visit with our favorite best friend.”

That breaks his silent treatment, and he starts squirming, because he knows who that statement is in reference to, and when Keigo got like that, it was brutal. “No! Wait! I’ll stop! Please no! I’ll stop! I promise!”

“No, no, you had your chance.” The blonde man carries him across their hotel room. “It’s too late, they’ve already put you into their schedule, there’s not stopping them now.”
